tasks.title: Initialize Next.js Project with TypeScript and Tailwind CSS
tasks.description: Set up a new Next.js project using the App Router, configured with TypeScript for type safety and Tailwind CSS for utility-first styling. This includes initializing the project, configuring Tailwind, and setting up the basic folder structure.
tasks.details: Use the command `npx create-next-app@latest --typescript --tailwind your-portfolio-app` to initialize the project. Configure `tailwind.config.ts` (e.g., theme extensions for colors, fonts if specified in Figma) and `postcss.config.js`. Create initial folders: `app/` for routes, `components/` for UI components, and `lib/data/` for hardcoded content.
tasks.testStrategy: Verify the project initializes correctly by running `npm run dev`. Check that TypeScript compiles without errors (`npm run build`). Apply a simple Tailwind class to the main page and ensure it renders correctly in the browser.

tasks.title: Implement Main Layout Component (`Layout.tsx`)
tasks.description: Create the main `Layout.tsx` component that will serve as a wrapper for all page content. This component will include the Navbar and Footer and provide a consistent structure across the application.
tasks.details:
The `Layout.tsx` component should be placed in the `components/` directory. It will accept `children: React.ReactNode` as props. The basic structure should be a flex container ensuring the footer stays at the bottom: `
{/* Placeholder for Navbar */}
{children}
{/* Placeholder for Footer */}
`. Import and render `Navbar` and `Footer` components once they are created.
tasks.testStrategy: Create a basic page within the `app` directory (e.g., `app/page.tsx`) that uses this `Layout` component. Verify that content passed as children renders correctly between the (placeholder) Navbar and Footer. Ensure the layout structure supports a sticky footer if content is short.

tasks.title: Implement Carousel for Featured Projects Section
tasks.description: Implement a responsive carousel for the Featured Projects section using `embla-carousel-react` to display project cards in a horizontally scrollable manner, replacing the current grid layout.
tasks.details:
1. Install `embla-carousel-react`: Run `npm install embla-carousel-react` or `yarn add embla-carousel-react`.
2. Create a reusable `Carousel.tsx` component, likely in `components/ui/Carousel.tsx`. This component will utilize the `useEmblaCarousel` hook from the library. It should accept `children` (the project cards) and optionally `options` for embla configuration. The basic structure will involve a viewport, a container for slides, and individual slide elements.
3. Style the `Carousel.tsx` component using Tailwind CSS to achieve a horizontal layout for slides and ensure it's responsive. Consider implementing optional previous/next navigation buttons and/or pagination dots, styled according to the project's dark theme and Figma design.
4. Update the existing `Projects.tsx` section component (in `components/sections/Projects.tsx`). Import and integrate the new `Carousel.tsx` component. Modify the logic to map over project data (e.g., from `projectData` in `lib/data/mockData.ts`) and render each `ProjectCard.tsx` (assuming this component exists from Task 10) as a slide within the carousel.
5. Remove the previous grid-based layout for project cards in `Projects.tsx`.
6. Ensure the carousel is fully responsive, adapting its appearance and behavior across mobile, tablet, and desktop screen sizes, consistent with the guidelines from Task 12 and the Figma design. Support touch gestures for navigation on mobile devices.
tasks.testStrategy:
1. Verify `embla-carousel-react` is correctly installed and listed in `package.json`.
2. Confirm the `Projects.tsx` section now displays project cards within a carousel structure, replacing any previous grid layout.
3. Test core carousel functionality: horizontal scrolling via mouse drag (if enabled) on desktop and swipe gestures on touch devices. All project cards from the mock data should be viewable.
4. If navigation buttons (previous/next) are implemented, verify they are correctly styled, functional, and appropriately enabled/disabled at the carousel ends.
5. If pagination dots are implemented, verify they accurately reflect the number of slides, highlight the active slide, and allow navigation on click.
6. Test responsiveness thoroughly across various viewport sizes (e.g., 320px, 375px, 768px, 1024px, 1440px). Ensure the carousel layout, item visibility, and controls adapt correctly without breaking the page layout or causing overflow.
7. Visually inspect the carousel against the Figma design for adherence to specified horizontal layout, spacing, project card appearance within the carousel, and overall dark theme consistency.
8. Check the browser console for any errors or warnings related to the carousel implementation during interaction.
9. Perform basic accessibility checks: ensure carousel controls are keyboard focusable and operable.

tasks.title: Implement Advanced Animations and Micro-interactions
tasks.description: Implement advanced animations and micro-interactions to enhance user experience, focusing on the desktop version initially. This includes smooth inertia scrolling, scroll-based section reveals, and interactive effects on components.
tasks.details: Integrate a library like Framer Motion (`npm install framer-motion`) to handle the animations. 1. **Inertia Scroll:** Implement a smooth scrolling library like `Lenis` to replace the native browser scroll, providing a more fluid, premium feel. This will involve wrapping the main layout in the Lenis provider. 2. **Scroll-based Reveals:** Wrap each main section component (`About`, `Skills`, `Background`, `Projects`) in a `motion` component from Framer Motion. Use the `useInView` hook or `whileInView` prop to trigger fade-in or slide-in animations as the section enters the viewport. Example: `<motion.section initial={{ opacity: 0, y: 50 }} whileInView={{ opacity: 1, y: 0 }} viewport={{ once: true, amount: 0.2 }} transition={{ duration: 0.5 }}>...</motion.section>`. 3. **Interactive Tilt Effect:** Apply a 3D tilt effect to the `ProjectCard.tsx` components within the carousel on hover. This can be achieved using a library like `react-parallax-tilt` or by using Framer Motion's `whileHover` with transform properties. 4. **Enhanced Hover Effects:** Refine hover states for interactive elements like navigation links and buttons. Use Framer Motion's `whileHover` prop to add subtle scale, translate, or background color transitions for a more dynamic feel.
tasks.testStrategy: 1. Verify that scrolling the page is noticeably smoother and has an inertia effect. 2. Scroll down the page from the top; confirm that each section animates into view as it enters the viewport. 3. Hover the mouse over the project cards in the featured projects carousel; verify that they exhibit a 3D tilt effect. 4. Hover over links in the Navbar and any other buttons; confirm they have the new, enhanced animation effects. 5. Check for performance issues using browser developer tools to ensure animations are smooth (maintain 60fps) and do not cause layout shifts or high CPU load.

tasks.details: Locate the `Layout.tsx` component and identify the `main` element or its primary child container that wraps the page content. This container likely has a restrictive `max-width` class (e.g., `max-w-3xl`) and `mx-auto` for centering. Modify these classes to apply a larger width for desktop screens. For example, change `className="... max-w-3xl"` to `className="... max-w-3xl lg:max-w-7xl"`. This will maintain the constrained width on mobile and tablet while allowing the content to expand on viewports 1024px and wider, providing more space for desktop-oriented layouts like multi-column sections.
tasks.testStrategy: 1. Run the application and open it in a browser with developer tools. 2. Set the viewport to a mobile width (e.g., 375px) and verify the content is constrained to its original max-width and centered. 3. Resize the viewport to be wider than the `lg` breakpoint (e.g., 1200px). 4. Confirm that the main content container expands to the new, larger `max-width` (e.g., `7xl`). 5. Ensure that all page content reflows correctly within the wider container and that no horizontal scrollbar appears.

tasks.title: Refine Section Components for Desktop Responsiveness
tasks.description: Update the internal layout and styling of all major content sections (`Hero`, `About`, `Background`, `Projects`, `Skills`, `Contact`) to match the desktop design on larger screens, while preserving the existing mobile-first styling.
tasks.details: This task involves applying responsive styles using Tailwind's `lg:` and `xl:` prefixes to adapt each section's internal layout for desktop viewports, following the completion of Task #17. The goal is to transition from single-column mobile layouts to more complex, multi-column, or spacious desktop layouts. Key changes include: - **Hero.tsx**: Transition from a `flex-col` layout to `lg:flex-row` with `lg:text-left`. Adjust spacing and image size for a side-by-side presentation. - **About.tsx**: Increase the `max-w` of the text container on large screens to improve line length and readability. - **Background.tsx**: Refine the timeline's spacing and alignment for wider viewports to ensure it doesn't look sparse. - **Projects.tsx**: Update the grid from `md:grid-cols-2` to `lg:grid-cols-3` to better utilize horizontal space. - **Skills.tsx**: Ensure the `flex-wrap` container has appropriate horizontal constraints and gaps on desktop. - **Contact.tsx**: Adjust form fields to be side-by-side or in a grid on desktop, instead of stacked vertically.
tasks.testStrategy: 1. Verify that all changes are applied only on viewports wider than the `lg` breakpoint (1024px). 2. Confirm that the mobile and tablet views (below 1024px) remain unchanged and functional, preserving the work from Task #12. 3. For each section on a large desktop viewport (>1200px): - **Hero**: Check for the side-by-side layout of the image and text. - **Projects**: Confirm the grid displays three columns. - **About/Background**: Ensure text is readable and layout is balanced. - **Skills/Contact**: Verify that elements are well-distributed and do not appear stretched or cramped.
